title: Tufte’s principles (and how to avoid lying with axes)
text:
This page is a small, visual reminder of a few ideas from Edward Tufte:
We’ll illustrate that with a simple example from the gapminder dataset.
library(tidyverse)
library(gapminder)

title: Tufte’s principles (and how to avoid lying with axes)
section: Example: life expectancy in Peru before 1980
text:
Example: life expectancy in Peru before 1980

life_exp_pre80 <- gapminder %>%
  filter(country == "Peru", year < 1980)


1) A misleading plot (truncated y‑axis)
This plot zooms the y‑axis to a narrow range.
It makes the improvement in life expectancy look much larger than it really is.

life_exp_pre80 %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, fill = as.factor(year))) +
  geom_col() +
  theme_light() +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(43.9, 60)) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 43.9, color = "red", size = 2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 58.45, color = "red", size = 2) +
  geom_label(
    aes(x = 1960, y = 58.45, fill = NULL),
    label = "Ratio is about 4.5",
    size = 10
  )










2) The honest version (axis starts at zero)
Same data, same geom, same colors.
Only the axis range is fixed so the magnitude is not exaggerated.

life_exp_pre80 %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, fill = as.factor(year))) +
  geom_col() +
  theme_light() +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 60)) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 43.9, color = "red", size = 2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 58.45, color = "red", size = 2) +
  geom_label(
    aes(x = 1960, y = 58.45, fill = NULL),
    label = "Ratio is about 1.3",
    size = 10
  )










Quick check (the real ratio)

max_life_exp <- life_exp_pre80 %>% slice_max(lifeExp)
min_life_exp <- life_exp_pre80 %>% slice_min(lifeExp)

max_life_exp$lifeExp / min_life_exp$lifeExp

[1] 1.331306




3) A deliberately “bad” example (what not to do)
This plot is purposely overloaded. It demonstrates the classic mistakes that Tufte warns about: too much background, heavy gridlines, loud colors, and no clear message.
Goal: Help students see how easily a plot can become cluttered.

gapminder %>%
    filter(country == "Peru", year < 1980) %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, fill = as.factor(year))) +
        geom_col() +
        theme(
            panel.grid.major = element_line(size = 1, linetype = 'dashed', colour = "green"),
            panel.grid.minor = element_line(size = 1, linetype = 'dashed', colour = "blue"),
            panel.background = element_rect(fill = "red", colour = "blue"),
            plot.background = element_rect(fill = "green")
        )










4) A cleaned-up reference version
Same data, but now the plot is readable. The layout is simple, the background is neutral, and unnecessary visual elements are removed.
Goal: Show the transition from visual noise to a reasonable starting point.

gapminder %>%
    filter(country == "Peru", year < 1980) %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, fill = as.factor(year))) +
        geom_col() +
        theme_light() +
        theme(legend.position = "none")










5) Highlighting one meaningful value (Tufte-ish)
Here we finally work with visual hierarchy: one bar (1967) is emphasized while everything else fades into the background. No gridlines, minimal text, and clear focus on the information that matters.
Goal: Demonstrate that a minimalist plot can be far more informative than a decorative one.

gapminder %>%
    filter(country == "Peru", year < 1980) %>%
    ggplot(aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, fill = (year == 1967))) +
        geom_col() +
        theme_minimal() +
        theme(
            axis.text.y = element_blank(),
            legend.position = "none") +
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("gray", "red")) +
    geom_text(
    aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, label = round(lifeExp)), nudge_y = 0.25, size = 7, vjust = 2, color = "black")

title: Tufte’s principles (and how to avoid lying with axes)
text:
Take-home message

If your axis does not start at zero, explain why and check that it does not distort the story.
Prefer clarity over decoration.
The “best” theme is the one that makes the data the easiest to read.
Highlight only what carries meaning. Silence around the important signal helps it stand out.

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
This page shows how different ggplot2 themes change the same plot. We keep the data and geoms fixed, and only swap the theme.
Use it as inspiration when polishing your own figures.

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
Data
We use a custom-prepared subset of personality questionnaire data based on the Big Five Inventory (BFI) included in the psych R package by William Revelle (Northwestern University).
Original data source: Revelle, W. (2024). psych: Procedures for Psychological, Psychometric, and Personality Research. Available from CRAN: https://cran.r-project.org/package=psych
What we use here:

the original BFI dataset (25 self-report items + demographics),
scored into five trait scales using psych::scoreItems(),
cleaned, labeled, and saved as bfi_traits.csv for teaching purposes.

If you want to reproduce the processed file, see src/data_prep/bfi_traits.R.

 Download the dataset (bfi_traits.csv) 


library(tidyverse)

# Load prepared dataset (created by src/data_prep/bfi_traits.R)
scores <- read_csv2("../assets/data/bfi_traits.csv")

# Base plot: keep geometry constant, no explicit theme here
base_plot <- scores %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = agree:openness,
    names_to = "trait",
    values_to = "score"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    gender = factor(gender, labels = c("Male", "Female")),
    trait = factor(
      trait,
      levels = c("agree", "conscientious", "extraversion", "neuroticism", "openness"),
      labels = c("Agreeable", "Conscientious", "Extraversion", "Neuroticism", "Openness")
    )
  ) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = trait, y = score, fill = gender)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(
    x = "BFI trait",
    y = "Score",
    title = "BFI scores by gender"
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    name = "Gender",
    values = c("#008000", "#800080")
  ) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(gender), labeller = label_value)

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
Default look (no theme added)
This is what ggplot uses by default (theme_gray()).

base_plot

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_gray()
The default ggplot theme with a light gray background.
Good when you want a “standard R look” or to emphasize the data over styling.

base_plot + theme_gray()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_minimal()
Very light, low‑ink design.
Nice for slides and papers when you want the plot to feel airy and modern.

base_plot + theme_minimal()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_classic()
White background, clear axes, no gridlines.
Great for simple teaching plots and for publications where grids feel cluttered.

base_plot + theme_classic()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_bw()
Black‑and‑white theme with grids.
A safe “journal‑style” default, especially for printing.

base_plot + theme_bw()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_light()
Similar to theme_gray() but lighter and cleaner.
Good when you want grids, but less visual weight.

base_plot + theme_light()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_linedraw()
Crisp black lines with minimal distractions.
Useful for technical figures and when you expect black‑and‑white reproduction.

base_plot + theme_linedraw()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_dark()
Dark background with light grids.
Can work on dark slides, or when you want a dramatic contrast.

base_plot + theme_dark()

title: Theme showcase: one plot, many looks
text:
theme_void()
Removes everything except the data.
Good for artistic visuals, insets, or when you add your own annotations later.

base_plot + theme_void()

title: Two-layer scatterplot
text: This task trains the basic ggplot workflow: mapping aesthetics, adding layers, and reading a smooth trend.

title: Two-layer scatterplot
text:
Goal
Replicate a scatterplot with a smooth trend line.
Focus first on structure (layers), then on style.

title: Two-layer scatterplot
text:
Load and preview data
We will use the built-in cars dataset (speed vs. stopping distance) from the tidyverse package


Show solution
library(tidyverse)

head(cars)


  speed dist
1     4    2
2     4   10
3     7    4
4     7   22
5     8   16
6     9   10

title: Two-layer scatterplot
section: Step 1: Start with a basic scatterplot
text:
Step 1: Start with a basic scatterplot


Show solution
ggplot(cars, aes(x = speed, y = dist)) +
  geom_point()









What to notice: * ggplot(data, aes(...)) defines what is plotted. * geom_point() draws the points.

title: Two-layer scatterplot
text:
Step 2: Improve readability of points


Show solution
ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +
  geom_point(size = 2)









Hints: * size changes point size. * alpha makes points semi-transparent (helps with overplotting).

title: Two-layer scatterplot
section: Step 3: Add a smooth trend line
text:
Step 3: Add a smooth trend line


Show solution
ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(se = TRUE)









Hints: * geom_smooth() adds a model-based trend. * se = TRUE shows a confidence band (gray ribbon).

title: Two-layer scatterplot
section: Step 4: Tune the smooth (optional but closer to target)
text:
Step 4: Tune the smooth (optional but closer to target)


Show solution
ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = TRUE)









Notes: * LOESS gives a flexible curve (good for small datasets). * Line color and thickness are styling details.

title: Two-layer scatterplot
text:
Step 5: Final polish (labels + clean theme)
Hints: * make points a little more transparent (70%) * add labs and title + x-axis label “Speed (mph)” + y-axis label “stopping distance (ft)” + plot title “Cars: speed and stopping distance” * set size of all text in the plot to 14 points


Show solution
ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +
  geom_point(size = 2, alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", se = TRUE) +
  labs(
    x = "Speed (mph)",
    y = "Stopping distance (ft)",
    title = "Cars: speed and stopping distance"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)

title: Two-layer scatterplot
text:
Extra challenges

Remove the gray confidence band.
Try a linear trend instead of LOESS.
Change the point color and add a matching smooth line.

title: Statistics with R – practical walkthrough
text:
Learn statistics through short, focused tasks in R. Each topic combines explanation, hands-on code, and a foldable solution, so you can check your work step by step.



  

Basic data exploration


Level 0 • essentials


Mean, median, SD, missing values, frequency tables, and random simulation basics.




  

Correlation


Level 1 • relationships between variables


Compute Pearson/Spearman correlations, interpret results, and visualize relationships.




  

Linear Regression


Level 1 • prediction & interpretation


Fit linear models, interpret coefficients, visualize predictions, and check model assumptions.




  

Group Comparisons


Level 1 • t-tests & ANOVA


Compare groups using t-tests and ANOVA, inspect effect sizes, and visualize differences.




  

Probability & Simulation


Level 1 • randomness & intuition


Roll virtual dice, simulate events, estimate probabilities, and build intuition through code.




  

Power & Sample Size


Level 1 • planning studies


Understand statistical power, compute required sample sizes, and explore effect size scenarios.

title: Basics: Working With Data in R
text:
This page covers the most practical basics you need before doing any statistics in R:

loading data
exploring structure
handling missing values
descriptive statistics
basic tables and proportions
random number generation
checking simple distribution shapes

You can use any dataset, but for this tutorial we work with:
perfectionism_total_scores.csv Small psychological teaching dataset containing one continuous variable: total maladaptive perfectionism score (FMPS_total). The data were adapted from the de-identified adult sample in Ferrari et al. (2018) and simplified for classroom use. In the original study, maladaptive perfectionism was computed as a combined score of four Frost Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (FMPS) subscales: Concern over Mistakes, Parental Expectations, Parental Criticism, and Doubts about Actions.
Original study: Ferrari, M., Yap, K., Scott, N., Einstein, D. A., & Ciarrochi, J. (2018). Self-compassion moderates the perfectionism and depression link in both adolescence and adulthood. PLOS ONE, 13(2), e0192022. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0192022 ￼
Questionnaires used in the original study:

Frost Multidimensional Perfectionism Scale (FMPS) — 35 items. Used to derive maladaptive perfectionism (FMPS_total).
Self-Compassion Scale – Short Form (SCS-SF) — 12 items. Total self-compassion score (SELF_C).
Depression Anxiety Stress Scales – Short Form (DASS-21) — 21 items. Subscales for depression, anxiety, and stress.

Variables in our teaching file: - FMPS_total — total maladaptive perfectionism score (higher = more maladaptive perfectionism). - DASS_Depress — depression symptoms. - DASS_Anx — anxiety symptoms. - DASS_Stress — stress symptoms. - SELF_C — total self-compassion score.
Note: The teaching dataset keeps only variables needed for introductory analyses and may differ slightly in coding/format from the original supporting files.

 Download the dataset (perfectionism_total_scores.csv) 


library(tidyverse)
df <- read_csv2("../assets/data/perfectionism_total_scores.csv")

Remove NA values from score and compute the mean of the cleaned vector.

sum(is.na(df$FMPS_total))

[1] 0

df_noNA <- df %>% drop_na(FMPS_total)

For categorical variables we would use table() and prop.table(). Here we artificially convert scores into categories:
Convert scores into three groups (your own cut points) and compute their proportions.

df_cat <- df %>%
  mutate(level = case_when(
    FMPS_total < 30 ~ "Low",
    FMPS_total < 60 ~ "Medium",
    TRUE ~ "High"
  ))

table(df_cat$level)


  High    Low Medium 
   264     11    240 

prop.table(table(df_cat$level)) %>% round(3)


  High    Low Medium 
 0.513  0.021  0.466 





Generate 20 random values from a normal distribution with mean 70 and sd 15.

set.seed(42)
x <- rnorm(100, mean = 50, sd = 10)
head(x)

[1] 63.70958 44.35302 53.63128 56.32863 54.04268 48.93875


Why set.seed()? It makes randomness reproducible.



Not a hypothesis test — just a visual check.
Inspect the histogram and Q-Q plot. Does the distribution look roughly normal?

df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = FMPS_total)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, fill = "#5c6bc0") +
  theme_minimal()







df %>%
  ggplot(aes(sample = FMPS_total)) +
  stat_qq() +
  stat_qq_line(color = "red") +
  theme_minimal()












Always start with glimpse(), summary(), head()
Use na.rm = TRUE when needed
table() + prop.table() are essential for categorical summaries
set.seed() ensures reproducible randomness
Quick plots often reveal more than formal tests

Basics: Working With Data in R
text:
Compute the mean, median, and standard deviation of the score.

# Mean
mean(df$FMPS_total, na.rm = TRUE)

title: Basics: Working With Data in R
text:
For categorical variables we would use table() and prop.table(). Here we artificially convert scores into categories:
Convert scores into three groups (your own cut points) and compute their proportions.

df_cat <- df %>%
  mutate(level = case_when(
    FMPS_total < 30 ~ "Low",
    FMPS_total < 60 ~ "Medium",
    TRUE ~ "High"
  ))

table(df_cat$level)


  High    Low Medium 
   264     11    240 

prop.table(table(df_cat$level)) %>% round(3)


  High    Low Medium 
 0.513  0.021  0.466

title: Basics: Working With Data in R
text:
Not a hypothesis test — just a visual check.
Inspect the histogram and Q-Q plot. Does the distribution look roughly normal?

df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = FMPS_total)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, fill = "#5c6bc0") +
  theme_minimal()







df %>%
  ggplot(aes(sample = FMPS_total)) +
  stat_qq() +
  stat_qq_line(color = "red") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Basics: Working With Data in R
text:
Always start with glimpse(), summary(), head()
Use na.rm = TRUE when needed
table() + prop.table() are essential for categorical summaries
set.seed() ensures reproducible randomness
Quick plots often reveal more than formal tests
